question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
The Taylor expansion of cos(x) is

\[\begin{aligned} \cos(x) = 1- \frac{x^2}{2!} + \frac{x^4}{4!} +\cdots = 1- \frac{x^2}2 + \frac{x^4}{24}+ \cdots\end{aligned}\]

Keeping the terms up to x2, we get

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1-\cos(x)}{x} \approx \frac{ x^2/2}{x} = \frac{x}{2}\end{aligned}\]

Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^1 \frac{1-\cos(x)} x \,dx \approx \int_0^1 \frac{x}{2} \,dx = \left.\frac{x^2}{4}\right|_0^1 = 1/4\end{aligned}\]

So 1/4 is a good approximation. Note that taking more terms of the Taylor expansions of cos(x) would simply yield an even better approximation.
sols_raw:
The Taylor expansion of cos(''x'') is 

:<math>
\cos(x) = 1- \frac{x^2}{2!} + \frac{x^4}{4!} +\cdots = 1- \frac{x^2}2 + \frac{x^4}{24}+ \cdots
</math>

Keeping the terms up to ''x''<sup>2</sup>, we get
:<math>
\frac{1-\cos(x)}{x} \approx \frac{ x^2/2}{x} = \frac{x}{2}
</math>

Therefore
:<math>
\int_0^1 \frac{1-\cos(x)} x \,dx \approx \int_0^1 \frac{x}{2} \,dx = \left.\frac{x^2}{4}\right|_0^1 = 1/4
</math>

So 1/4 is a good approximation. Note that taking more terms of the Taylor expansions of cos(''x'') would simply yield an even better approximation.
